text: (upbeat music)
- Hey everybody.

We've got a really exciting
video coming to you this week

about our top 10 bucket
list travel destinations
that you have to visit before you die.

- So you've been cooped up
for more than a year now.
You've been inside for way too long
and you're just itching to get outside.
- So we thought, why not scour all

the amazing trips that
we've taken since 2010,
and come up with these exciting trips
that you can put on your bucket list.

But before we get started,
we wanna let you know

that we will be sharing
more travel ideas coming up.
So make sure you subscribe to our channel

and click the bell so
you get notifications

when those videos are
ready for you to watch.
- [Deb] So let's get started.
- Let's go on safari.
(dynamic music)

- When putting together a
travel bucket list dream board
it just wouldn't be complete
if you didn't include an African safari.

It's just one of the best things
to do in anyone's lifetime.

- Definitely, and one of
the great places to do it
is on the Serengeti in Tanzania.

We're about to enter the
Ngorongoro Conservation Area
and off to the Serengeti, let's go!
And actually, Serengeti translated
from Maasai actually means endless plains.
And let me tell you,

the Serengeti is 12,000 square
miles of endless plains.
It certainly lives up to the hype.
- Now everybody goes to see the big five.
And what are the big five days, Dave?
- The big five are buffalo, rhino,
elephant, lion, and leopard.
That was pretty good, eh.
- That was well done.

Seeing all of these animals
just living in harmony
on the plains of the Serengeti,
it's really an uplifting experience.

And it's something that
I think we all need
after this very dark year that we've had.
- Most definitely.

- Ladies and gentlemen, welcome
to the Ngorongoro Crater.

- Now safaris, they can
range in different prices
depending on who you book with
and what kind of trip you want.
- Yeah, we went with Go Ahead Tours

and it was a really great
mix of luxury and camping,
and a little bit of ruggedness.
Had a lot of cultural experiences as well,
and I really highly recommend it.
But you can do budget safaris.

If you go right into
Tanzania, and have the time,
and book with a local tour operator
you can get some safaris for pretty cheap.

For the most part, if you're
gonna book a Tanzania safari

expect to pay anywhere
between 2,000 and $5,000.

- It's worth it.
- It is.

- One of the things I've
loved here on this trip

in Tanzania is the eclectic
mix of accommodations.

You have tented camps,
you have luxury lodges,

lodges inside the park,
lodges outside the park.

It's just such a great
way to experience Africa.

Now going on safari in
Africa in the Serengeti,
or wherever you decide to do it,
it's more than just about the wildlife.
It's really an all round type of trip.
There's obviously the wildlife viewing,

and there's cultural experiences,
there's incredible food.
And getting to know the locals is really
part of why you will fall in love
with this part of the world.
(dynamic music)

Now Bhutan is one of the least
visited countries on Earth.

And for that reason alone, it
should be on your bucket list.
There's a lot to explore there
other than just the Himalayas,

but that's kind of the focus
when you're going to Bhutan.
- [Deb] Definitely.

- Most trips in Bhutan
definitely include Paro,
the city of Paro, because there

is the world famous
Tiger's Nest monastery.
Which is just stunning to see unto itself.

It's about a two hour
hike to get up there.

And the scenery all the
way up is pretty amazing.
But once you get up there and look at this

you can just imagine
what it would be like,

the monks living in this
very remote monastery
that is perched on the side of a cliff.
No wonder everybody goes there.

- But then there are a lot
of other treks to be had.

It's one of the greatest
destinations for trekking on Earth.

And you can do something
for as little as two days,
to seriously, 25 days.
It's home to the Snowman Trek,

which is considered the
toughest trek on Earth.

- Bhutan is also known as
the country of festivals.

They have festivals it
seems like almost every week
in almost every city.
I know when we were there

we went to the Highlander
Festival, which took place

up in a small remote
village in the Himalayas.
But there's different festivals

in all different cities
throughout the country.

- And a very fun fact,
during our time that we

went to the Highlander
Festivals up in Laya
we met the King of Bhutan.
- So we just talked to the King.
As you can see Deb was really excited,

and so was I, we were
almost kind of stammering.

Not allowed to take any
photo photos or video of him,
but it really did happen.

And you can really see why he
is called the People's King.

He walked down the line
and he talked to everybody.
He's very humble.

And you could tell he really
loves this beautiful country.
One of the reasons Bhutan is one of
the least visited countries in the world

is probably because it
does have a tourist fee
of $250 per person, per day.
Now this includes your guide,
your food, and your accommodation.
So it's not too bad.
And it's really worth it to have
a guide and everything included

because everything in the
country is quite remote.

So you wanna have that
looked after for you.
- And I think it's worth it.
I think it helps with over tourism.
And it supports the economy.
- Spectacular!
- Like so many places in the world,
the most important thing about traveling
is getting to know the locals.

We still keep in touch with
some of our friends from Bhutan

and they really are the
friendliest people on Earth.
- [Dave] They are.

- Look it.
- See you inside.

Let's go.
- Okay.
(dynamic music)
- Here we go everybody,
we're entering the Great Wall of China.
Let's go.
When we were putting together this list
of bucket list destinations,

we definitely had to add
the Great Wall of China.
We've had the luxury of visiting China,
or the Great Wall of China two times.

We've gone to the one at
Badaling and the one at Mutianyu.
I think I'm pronouncing--

- Mutianyu.
- Mutianyu, okay.

I think I'm pronouncing that
right, obviously I'm not.
And they really did live up to the hype.

It's pretty amazing to see
this feat of engineering.
A lot of it has been rebuilt,
and you can go up there and walk on it.
And you can just imagine what it was like
when it was being built,

and why it was built
as an amazing defense.
(upbeat music)
- We are on the Great Wall.
We're walking up to the towers right now.
This is the iconic one that you see
on all the magazines, and on TV.
It's very exciting.
There's hardly any tourists here,

it's mostly locals that are
here visiting the Great Wall.
So it's really cool to experience it
with everybody that is here from China.
- It's getting steep.
- We made it to the top.
That is a steep climb, everybody.
Woo!
And it's a traffic jam too.
It's absolutely incredible.

And it really is one
of the top destinations
for your bucket list on Earth.
- And that was the Great Wall of China.
(dynamic music)

- Something that was
always on my bucket list
of travels was the Amazon River.

And when I got the chance to
go there, I was so excited

because this is the
biggest river in the world.
Well, it's the biggest by water volume.
The Am, no, the Amazon's number two,
and the Nile is just a little bit longer.

But what's really special
about this is that
the Amazon River just takes you way

deep into the heart of
the Amazon Rainforest.
And that's what's really cool about it.
This river is wild, and vast, and fast.

- Yeah, and one of the
things I really loved
about going down the Amazon was actually

getting on the skiff boats,
and getting out there

into the jungle, and
also meeting the people.

But the wildlife there
was pretty cool as well.
You got to see spider monkeys,

we saw pink dolphins, there
were three-toed sloths.
Like if wildlife is something
that you are really interested in,
then a cruise down the Amazon is something
you have to add to your bucket list.
- If you were out there alone,
you wouldn't see any wildlife.

Our guides were really
great at spotting it

because the Amazon is
really dense with jungle.
They would find it and then show it to us.

And it's just incredible
to have them spot it
with their eagle eyes.
They were just awesome.
- It's incredible.

I don't know how they do it,
obviously lots of training.

- [Deb] And we went with
International Expeditions.
And not only just training,

they had local guides who
really grew up in the area
and knew the area well.

- [Dave] And we got to stop
into some local villages.
So it's really interesting to see
how people go about their daily lives
and how they actually survive out there
on the shores of the Amazon River.
- We were on a really luxury boat.

We had entertainment nightly,
we had fantastic food.

We had our own private
suite with a balcony
that we could overlook the Amazon River
with our coffee in the morning.
And if you're gonna do a cruise like this
it's gonna set you back about $6,500.

And I think it is well worth
it for a trip of a lifetime.
- Cheers.

Great village visit, time
to head back to the boat.
(gentle music)
With Canada being our home country,

we can't leave it off
the bucket list list.

So a bucket list thing that
you have to do is head up

and drive the Dempster
Highway in Northern Canada.
It's this incredible road that goes
from the Arctic Circle all the way down
to the wild west town of Dawson City.
- This has to go on your bucket list
because it is the ultimate drive.
If you're looking for one road trip
to do in your life, this is it.
It's just so remote.
But what I loved about it is that
we didn't see barely any other cars.
There would be like one car
every few hours that we would pass.
- Let's go!
One thing you definitely get here
on the Dempster is beautiful scenery.

The Peel River going into
those mountains, it's perfect.
(gentle music)

- One of the unique things
about the Dempster Highway
is that we share the road with airplanes.
Yes, this is an airstrip.
And yes, planes do land right here.

- So far, the Dempster
Highway drive has been

everything I expected, beautiful
scenery, long open roads.

You really feel like you
have nature to yourself.

One of the things you'll
do on the Dempster Highway
is cross the Arctic Circle.

Right where I'm standing
is the Arctic Circle.
I'm not in the Arctic Circle.
I'm in the Arctic Circle.
- We are at the Peel-Ogilvie lookout,

and what a gorgeous
view this lookout offers

of the Ogilvie Mountains
and the Peel River Valley.
Beautiful, make sure you stop here
when you're doing the Dempster Highway.
- Well, ladies and gentlemen, we did it.
We drove the Dempster Highway all the way
from Inuvik down to Dawson City.
And let me tell you, it was awesome.
- And it deserves a kiss.
(jaunty music)
Welcome to Iguazu Falls.
- So when you come to Iguazu Falls

you have to make sure you stay
at the Hotel des Cataratas.
Why?

Because it is the only
hotel that is inside
Iguazu National Park.
And this gives you exclusive access
to when there's no crowds here.

So you can head down to
the falls at sunrise,
before the park opens.
And for sunset, when everybody has left.
It really gives you an exclusive access
to see all different parts of the park
without the crowds of people.

So if you're gonna visit one
waterfall in your lifetime
make it Iguazu Falls.
And what makes it unique is that
it's situated in the jungle,
surrounded by jungle and rainforest.
It's a unique location,

but it's also an absolutely
massive waterfall.
And you can take it in from above,
looking either you take a helicopter,
or the lookouts are pretty amazing.

But what I recommend is
to actually get down,
they have a boardwalk that goes
right along the bottom of the falls.
And that gives you a sense
of exactly how massive they really are.
- This is incredible!
(jaunty music)
Okay, I'm going shoes off.
I've got nothing with me but my GoPro.
We're heading to the jet boat.
Let's go.
Whoa, we're going in there.
- [Dave] How awesome is that?

- We're going in.
- That's awesome!
Woo!
(everyone shouting)
- That was wicked fun.
Welcome to Meteora.
(jaunty music)

- For me, a bucket list
destination is a place

that can look like no
other place on Earth.
And there's a place like that in Greece.
For a bucket list destination
you have to head to Meteora.

- This is the most incredible
landscape in a valley,
in the Meteora Valley.
It's massive, but what makes it even
more incredible is that there are
these monasteries built on top of them.
And they built these monasteries
on top in the ninth century.

- So before 1922, the
way that you got up here
was they put you in a small little net

and two monks would stay up
here and push that wheel around.
And as the rope got shorter and shorter
that's how you'd get up.
Quite an adventure.
You wanna climb up there?

And it does look like
something out of a movie,
or that was computer generated.
Like when you look at it, you're like, oh,
how can this actually be real?
But when, there's lots of different hikes
that you can do around there.
So you can go hiking through them,
you can actually climb up and get into

a few of the monasteries to
see how they actually lived.

And even the town itself
is an attraction as well.
- Something I love about exploring Meteora
are all of the high lookout points
that you can do to explore
and see the city of Kalabaka behind me.
I think it's one of the most beautiful
city settings on Earth.
Having these gorgeous stone pillars
just jutting out from the town.

And you can do this by car, by
foot, by bicycle, by scooter.

You just have to make sure
you come to the high lookouts.
- Now that is a view.
If you're a "Game of Thrones" fan,
you'll definitely recognize this view.
(jaunty music)
Meteora is a photographer's dream.
So when you come to Greece,

make sure that you add
Meteora to your itinerary.
It's got beautiful views, amazing food,
and great history and culture.
You won't regret it.
Ciao.
(upbeat music)
- [Both] Cheers.
- From Cappadocia.

Have you ever seen those
photos on Instagram,
or on your Facebook,
with all those balloons in the sky,

with all those fairy chimneys
jutting out of the ground?

Well that's the next
item on our bucket list
destinations to see before you die.

- And we are talking
about Cappadocia, Turkey.

This place is again like a
bit of a lunar landscape,

or like something that's
out of another planet.
And the best way to appreciate it

is to take a hot air balloon
ride over top of it at sunrise.
No wonder they do it at sunrise
'cause really that's the time to see it,
with the sun just coming over the edge.

And you're not the only
balloon in the air there.

Like Deb said, you see those
photos with all those balloons.
It's really like that.

There are multitudes,
probably hundreds of balloons
going up at the same time every morning.

It's amazing they don't
crash into each other.
What an amazing balloon ride here.

When you come to Cappadocia
do it with Royal.
- Yeah, they're good.

We've done it twice now
and this is the better one.

- By far.
- Yeah.
And when you go there, make sure you spend

more than just a day to take
the hot air balloon ride.
You have to walk around the entire area

because there's caves to
explore, there's walking trails.

There's the incredible
monoliths and the landscape.

And when you do stay over,
stay in a cave hotel.
- Yeah, that's pretty cool.

All these caves that have
been there for centuries
have been turned into hotels.

So people used to live in
these small little caves,

but now they've turned into
these luxury accommodations.

So why not pair a bucket list
trip by going up in a balloon,
by staying in a cave hotel.
Come on, it's gotta be on your list.
- The great thing about Turkey
is that it's quite affordable.
What you get for five star in Turkey
you would pay a fortune for here
in some place like New York City.
(dynamic music)
- Welcome to Petra, here in Jordan.
(dramatic music)

The Middle East is full
of a lot of history
and some really incredible destinations.
But one that really stood out to me

and I wanted to put on
this bucket list list
was Petra in Jordan.

- What's so amazing about
it is that it was hidden

for so many years because
it's in the center
of this massive rock formation.

You have to walk for
a kilometer and a half

through a narrow gorge
to get to an opening,
which is really like this big square,
what it used to be, the public square.
And it is the treasury.

And once you've come along
this big narrow gorge

of rocks jutting up on
either side and then come out

to this massive building that's
been carved into the rock,

you just can't believe
that this is even possible.
- Heading up to the monastery here.
There's I think 800 steps.
So getting our legs in shape.
So behind me is the monastery.
It was 800 steps to get up here.
As you can see, it was well worth it.
Now a lot of people actually say

that they like the monastery
better than the treasury.
Jury's still out on that for me.

But I like them both just
the same as it stands now.
And it doesn't end there.
You continue going and there's different,
small carved out buildings in the rock.
You can spend a whole day exploring
the whole lost city of Petra.

And you can actually
head on up and look over,
there's a few lookouts there where you can

look over both the
treasury and the monastery.

Ladies and gentlemen,
the end of the world.
(dramatic music)
- So, this is Petra.

What an amazing day we had at
the ancient city in Jordan,
in the Middle East.
- Welcome to Antarctica
(upbeat music)

Bucket list destinations are
about experiences for sure,
but they're also about bragging rights.

And this next destination is
all about bragging rights.
We're talking about Antarctica.
- It's the mother of all travels.
- Dun, dun, dun.

- It's the seventh continent,
the final frontier.
- So we made it here.
Our seventh continent, Antarctica.

We've stepped on the
actual continent today.
Woo hoo!
- [Deb] It was a dream.

It was a dream vacation the
entire time we were there.
Seeing all of this wildlife
that isn't even afraid of human beings.

- Yeah, really, you can have
wildlife experiences there

like you can't have
anywhere else in the world.
There's something special about going
to a place where people don't inhabit.
There's no tourism down there as far as
things set up on the island.
And when you're down there on a ship,

which is the way to do
it, on an expedition ship,

you're out there discovering
different channels,
and different areas of Antarctica

that open up at different
times of the year.
So every trip is different.
- Penguins would jump in front of you.
They would come up and sit on your lap.
It was just an incredible destination.

- So we've made it here
to the Shetland Islands,

which is our first stop
here with Park Expeditions.
And we get to see tons of penguins.

And, you know, if you sit
down and be really quiet,

and sit there and be calm,
they'll come right up to you.

We have to stay five
meters away from them,

but they can come up as
close as they want to you.
It's really, truly a great experience.

- My favorite thing to do is
to just get out on the zodiac

looking for whales, and
looking for leopard seals,

and Weddell seals, and
circling around icebergs.
So we've just had an amazing experience.
A couple of humpback whales just went

right under our boat and right,
they were just meters away.
It was so incredible.

I've never been that close
to a whale in my life,
down here in Antarctica, very cool.
- If you're an adventurer like we are,
and when you're down there,
I highly recommend doing the kayaking.

It's an option for a lot of
the cruises that go down there.
There's something special about being
at the level with wildlife.
You're up a little bit on the zodiac,
and you're going pretty fast.
But paddling through brash ice

and having a minke whale come
up and surface beside you.
It's experiences like that

that make this the ultimate
bucket list destination.

Now I did say there is no
accommodations down there,
but that's kind of not really true

because you can get the
opportunity to actually
camp on the continent of Antarctica.
- Well, this is home for the night.
This is my sleeping bag and my bivy.
Made a nice little bed in the snow.
And we're camping in Antarctica, man.
- Now, a bucket list trip like this,
or the ultimate bucket list trip,
it's gonna set you back a few bucks.

I mean, there's a reason
why not so many people
actually make it to Antarctica.
And usually it's because of cost.

A lot of the trips they start
at about $10,000 per person.
So you'll wanna save up for this one.

But let me tell you,
it's money well spent.

that we say you have to do before you die.
